questions.question: For a given take-off mass, the maximum brake energy limit speed (V<sub>MBE</sub>), as an indicated airspeed, will:

options.content: decrease with increasing altitude, and decrease with increasing temperature
increase with increasing altitude and increase with increasing temperature
decrease with increasing altitude, and increase with increasing temperature
not change with altitude, but decrease with increasing temperature

questions.question: Provided all other parameters stay constant, which of the following statements will decrease the take-off ground run?

options.content: Decreased take-off mass, increased pressure altitude, increased temperature
Decreased take-off mass, increased density, increased flap setting
Increased pressure altitude, increased outside air temperature, increased takeoff mass
Increased outside air temperature, decreased pressure altitude, decreased flap setting

questions.question: A multi-engine aeroplane is flying at the minimum control speed (V<sub>MCA</sub>). Which parameter(s) must be maintainable after engine failure?

options.content: Heading, altitude and a positive rate of climb of 100 ft/min
Altitude
Straight flight
Straight flight and altitude

questions.question: How is V<sub>MCA</sub> influenced by increasing pressure altitude?

options.content: V<sub>MCA</sub> decreases with increasing pressure altitude
V<sub>MCA</sub> increases with pressure altitude higher than 4000 ft
V<sub>MCA</sub> increases with increasing pressure altitude
V<sub>MCA</sub> is not affected by pressure altitude

questions.question: Which of the following speeds can be limited by the ˋmaximum tyre speedˊ?

options.content: Lift-off ground speed
Lift-off IAS
Lift-off TAS
Lift-off EAS

questions.question: A higher outside air temperature (OAT):

options.content: decreases the brake energy limited take-off mass
increases the field length limited take-off mass
increases the climb limited take-off mass
decreases the take-off distance

questions.question: The take-off performance requirements for Class A transport category aeroplanes are based upon:

options.content: failure of critical engine
failure of critical engine or all engines operating whichever gives the largest take-off distance
all engines operating
only one engine operating

questions.question: Maximum and minimum values of V1 can be limited by:

options.content: V<sub>R</sub> and V<sub>MGC</sub>
V<sub>2</sub> and V<sub>MCA</sub>
V<sub>R</sub> and V<sub>MCA</sub>
V<sub>2</sub> and V<sub>MGC</sub>

questions.question:
During the certification flight testing of a twin-engine turbojet aeroplane, the actual demonstrated take-off distances are equal to:

1547 m with all engines operating

1720 m with failure of the critical engine at V1 and with all other things remaining unchanged

The take-off distance adopted for the certification file is:
The minimum value that V2 must exceed “air minimum control speed” is by:
With regard to a take-off from a wet runway, which of the following statements is correct?

options.content: Screen height cannot be reduced
The screen height can be lowered to reduce the mass penalties
When the runway is wet, the V<sub>1</sub> reduction is sufficient to maintain the same margins on the runway length
In case of a thrust reverser inoperative, the wet runway performance information can still be used

questions.question: Balanced V<sub>1</sub> is selected:

options.content: for a runway length limited take-off with a clearway to give the highest mass
if it is equal to V<sub>2</sub>
if the accelerate-stop distance required is equal to the one engine out take-off distance required
for a runway length limited take-off with a stopway to give the highest mass

questions.question: How is V<sub>2</sub> affected if take-off flaps at 20° is chosen instead of take-off flaps at 10°?

options.content: V<sub>2</sub> increases in proportion to the angle at which the flaps are set
V<sub>2</sub> has no connection with take-off flap setting, as it is a function of runway length only
V<sub>2</sub> decreases if not restricted by V<sub>MCA</sub>
V<sub>2</sub> has the same value in both cases

questions.question: Which statement regarding the influence of a runway downslope is correct for a balanced take-off? Downslope:

options.content: increases V<sub>1</sub> and reduces the accelerate-stop distance required (ASDR)
reduces V<sub>1</sub> and increases the accelerate-stop distance required (ASDR)
increases V<sub>1</sub> and increases the take-off distance required (TODR)
reduces V<sub>1</sub> and reduces take-off distance required (TODR)

questions.question: Ignoring the minimum control speed limitation, the lowest take-off safety speed (V<sub>2min</sub>) is:

options.content: 1.15V<sub>S</sub> for all turbojet aeroplanes
1.20V<sub>S</sub> for all turboprop powered aeroplanes
1.13V<sub>SR</sub> for two-engine and three-engine turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes
1.13V<sub>SR</sub> for turbo-propeller powered aeroplanes with more than three engines

questions.question: During the flight preparation a pilot makes a mistake by selecting a V<sub>1</sub> greater than that required. Which problem will occur when the engine fails at a speed immediately above the correct value of V<sub>1</sub>?

options.content: The stop distance required will exceed the stop distance available
The one engine out take-off distance required may exceed the take-off distance available
V<sub>2</sub> may be too high so that climb performance decreases
It may lead to over-rotation

questions.question: The speed V<sub>2</sub> of a jet aeroplane must be greater than: (assume the aeroplane has provisions for obtaining a significant reduction in the one engine inoperative power-on stall speed.)

options.content: 1.13V<sub>MCG</sub>
1.05V<sub>LOF</sub>
1.3V<sub>1</sub>
1.08V<sub>SR</sub>

questions.question: When an aircraft takes off with the mass limited by the TODA or field length:

options.content: the actual take-off mass equals the field length limited take-off mass
the distance from brake release to V1 will be equal to the distance from V<sub>1</sub> to the 35 ft point
the “balanced take-off distance” equals 115% of the “all engine take-off distance”
the end of the runway will be cleared by 35 ft following an engine failure at V<sub>1</sub>

questions.question: A runway is contaminated by a 0.5 cm layer of wet snow. The take-off is nevertheless authorized by a light-twinˊs flight manual. The take-off distance in relation to a dry runway will be:

options.content: very significantly decreased
increased
unchanged
decreased

questions.question: What will be the influence on the aeroplane performance at higher pressure altitudes?

options.content: It will increase the take-off distance
It will decrease the take-off distance
It will increase the take-off distance available
It will increase the accelerate-stop distance available

questions.question: During certification test flights for a turbojet aeroplane, the actual measured takeoff runs from brake release to a point equidistant between the point at which V<sub>LOF</sub> is reached and the point at which the aeroplane is 35 ft above the take-off surface are:
The correct formulae are:

options.content: 1.05V<sub>MCA</sub> is less than or equal to V<sub>EF</sub>, V<sub>EF</sub> is less than or equal to V<sub>1</sub>
1.05V<sub>MCG</sub> is less than V<sub>EF</sub>, V<sub>EF</sub> is less than or equal to V<sub>R</sub>
V<sub>2MIN</sub> is less than or equal to V<sub>EF</sub>, V<sub>EF</sub> is less than or equal to V<sub>MU</sub>
V<sub>MCG</sub> is less than or equal to V<sub>EF</sub>, V<sub>EF</sub> is less than V<sub>1</sub>

questions.question: If the field length limited take-off mass has been calculated using a balanced field length technique, the use of any additional clearway in take-off performance calculations may allow:

options.content: a greater field length limited take-off mass but with a higher V<sub>1</sub>
the obstacle clearance limit to be increased with no effect on V<sub>1</sub>
the obstacle clearance limit to be increased with a higher V<sub>1</sub>
a greater field length limited take-off mass but with a lower V<sub>1</sub>

questions.question: The result of a higher flap setting up to the optimum at take-off is:

options.content: a higher V<sub>1</sub>
a longer take-off run
a shorter ground roll
an increased acceleration

questions.question: For Class A aeroplanes the take-off run is:

options.content: the horizontal distance along the take-off path from the start of the take-off to a point equidistant between the point at which V<sub>LOF</sub> is reached and the point at which the aeroplane is 35 ft above the take-off surface

1.5 times the distance from the point of brake release to a point equidistant between the point at which V<sub>LOF</sub> is reached and the point at which the aeroplane attains a height of 35 ft above the runway with all engines operative
1.15 times the distance from the point of brake release to the point at which V<sub>LOF</sub> is reached assuming a failure of the critical engine at V1

the distance of the point of brake release to a point equidistant between the point at which V<sub>LOF</sub> is reached and the point at which the aeroplane attains a height of 50 ft above the runway assuming a failure of the critical engine at V<sub>1</sub>

questions.question: Which statement is correct for a Class A aeroplane?

options.content: V<sub>R</sub> must not be less than 1.05V<sub>MCA</sub> and not less than 1.1V<sub>1</sub>
VR must not be less than 1.05V<sub>MCA</sub> and not less than V<sub>1</sub>
V<sub>R</sub> must not be less than V<sub>MCA</sub> and not less than 1.05V<sub>1</sub>
V<sub>R</sub> must not be less than 1.1V<sub>MCA</sub> and not less than V<sub>1</sub>

questions.question:
During certification flight testing on a four engine turbojet aeroplane the actual take-off distances measured are:

2555 m with all engines operating

3050 m with failure of the critical engine recognized at V1 and all other things being equal.

The take-off distance adopted for the certification file is:
When the outside air temperature increases, then:

options.content: the field length limited take-off mass decreases but the climb limited take-off mass increases
the field length limited take-off mass increases but the climb limited take-off mass decreases
the field length limited take-off mass and the climb limited take-off mass decreases
the field length limited take-off mass and the climb limited take-off mass increases

questions.question: In case of an engine failure which is recognized at or above V1:

options.content: the take-off should be rejected if the speed is still below V<sub>R</sub>
the take-off must be continued
the take-off must be rejected if the speed is still below V<sub>LOF</sub>
a height of 50 ft must be reached within the take-off distance

questions.question: V<sub>R</sub> cannot be lower than:

options.content: 105% of V<sub>1</sub> and V<sub>MCA</sub>
1.2V<sub>S</sub> for twin and three engine jet aeroplane
1.15V<sub>S</sub> for turboprop with three or more engines
V<sub>1</sub> and 105% of V<sub>MCA</sub>

questions.question: If the performance limiting take-off mass of an aeroplane is brake energy limited, a higher uphill slope would:

options.content: have no effect on the maximum mass for take-off
decrease the required take-off distance
increase the maximum mass for take-off
decrease the maximum mass for take-off

questions.question: In which of the following distances can the length of a stopway be included?

options.content: In the accelerate-stop distance available
In the one-engine failure case, take-off distance
In the all engine take-off distance
In the take-off run available

questions.question: In the event of engine failure below V<sub>1</sub>, the first action to be taken by the pilot in order to decelerate the aeroplane is to:

options.content: apply wheel brakes
deploy airbrakes or spoilers
reduce the engine thrust
reverse engine thrust

questions.question: Which is the correct sequence of speeds during take-off?

options.content: V<sub>1</sub>, V<sub>R</sub>, V<sub>2</sub>, V<sub>MCA</sub>
V<sub>MCG</sub>, V<sub>1</sub>, V<sub>R</sub>, V<sub>2</sub>
V<sub>1</sub>, V<sub>MCG</sub>, V<sub>R</sub>, V<sub>2</sub>
V<sub>1</sub>, V<sub>R</sub>, V<sub>MCG</sub>, V<sub>2</sub>

questions.question: Which of the following distances will increase if you increase V<sub>1</sub>?

options.content: All engine take-off distance
Take-off run
Accelerate-stop distance
Take-off distance

questions.question: If the value of the balanced V<sub>1</sub> is found to be lower than V<sub>MCG</sub>, which of the following is correct?

options.content: The ASDR will become greater than the one engine out take-off distance
The take-off is not permitted
The one engine out take-off distance will become greater than the ASDR
The V<sub>MCG</sub> will be lowered to V<sub>1</sub>

questions.question:
For this question use Figure 4.4 in CAP 698 Section 4.

For an example twin engine turbojet aeroplane two take-off flap settings (5° and 15°) are certified.
